acqinfo.p: Gift of Carol and Ted Hughes, 01/06/1997.

did.unittitle: Letter from A. Alvarez to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) commenting on poems Plath sent to him.

did.unittitle: Letter from A. Alvarez to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) saying he would love to see some of her latest poems.

did.unittitle: Copy of letter from Atlantic Monthly to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy of typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Edward Weeks, agreeing to include her "Circus in Three Rings" in their "group of young poets to appear in the August ATLANTIC." Copy probably typed by Aurelia Plath, with her notation in pen: "Was x'd out by editor & not used in Letters Home by Sylvia Plath."

did.unittitle: Letter from Atlantic Monthly Press to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Emilie Warren McLeod, telling her that she could not get Little Brown to share her enthusiasm for The Bed Book.

did.unittitle: Letter from Atlantic Monthly Press to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Peter H. Davison, Executive editor, returning 7 of her poems and keeping others for further consideration. In Plath's hand in lower left corner: "Jailor: The Bees: 5:"

did.unittitle: Letter from Ruth Beuscher to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed air letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, advising her about her marriage.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ruth Beuscher to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed air letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, discussing possible separation and divorce from Ted Hughes, hiring a nanny, and her children.

did.unittitle: Letter from British Broadcasting Corporation to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from B.H. Alexander, copyright department, detailing her payment for two poems ("Candles" and "Leaving Early") which she recorded for broadcast on a BBC program, "The Poet's Voice."

did.unittitle: Letter from British Broadcasting Corporation to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from Douglas Cleverdon, asking her if she would like to record a sequence of her poems. He also mentions having given Ted 5 copies of Plath's "Three Women."

did.unittitle: Letter from British Broadcasting Corporation to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from Douglas Cleverdon, concerning her script for "New Poems," her move into Yeats' house, and about sending one copy of "Three Women" to the "gynaecologist with a letter from yourself."

did.unittitle: Letter from British Broadcasting Corporation to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Leonie Cohn, making a suggestion about the syntax of her "sea script" and suggesting the title "Ocean 1212-W." She also asks when Plath could record it. Also: Obituary (photocopy) of Leonie Cohn (The Daily Telegraph, 2009 Sep 2).

did.unittitle: Letter from Michael Carey to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, part of an exchange of letters about writing and reading modern poetry. Letter is signed Fr. Michael (listed in Plath's address book as Rev. MC.J. Carey A.A.).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Sylvia Plath wrote five letters to Fr. Carey (1962-63). They are transcribed in an Appendix to Sylvia Plath: Confessing the Fictive Self by Toni Saldivar (New York: Peter Lang, 1992).

did.unittitle: Typed copy of a letter from Mary Ellen Chase to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed copy (carbon) of a signed letter to Sylvia Plath wishing her well as she departs on the S.S. Queen Elizabeth for her year as a Fulbright scholar in Cambridge, England. Typed by Aurelia Plath, who has added contextual comments and a note about whether or not the letter was included in Letters Home.

did.unittitle: Typed copy of letter from Mary Ellen Chase to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two typed copies (carbon only) of a letter to Sylvia Plath congratulating her on her appointment to teach at Smith College. Copies typed by Aurelia Plath, who has added contextual comments.

did.unittitle: Letter from Critical Quarterly to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Charles B. Cox, informing her that she has won one of two prizes in The Critical Quarterly poetry competition for her poem, Medallion.

did.unittitle: Letter from Critical Quarterly to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Tony (Anthony E.) Dyson, saying he is about to return to Wales, but hopes to see her again near Easter, he also mentions prices The Critical Quarterly can now pay for both poems and reviews and hopes she will send them more poems to publish.

did.unittitle: Letter from Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from the secretary of the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust, announcing the award of a Saxton grant to Sylvia Plath.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ruth Fainlight to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, discussing life in Morocco versus life in London and saying she looks forward to returning to London.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ruth Fainlight to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, announcing her return to London in early March, when she hopes to see Sylvia.

did.unittitle: Typed copy of a letter from Alfred Young Fisher to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter to Sylvia Plath, congratulating her on her marriage to Ted Hughes. Copy presumably typed by Aurelia Plath, with her contextual notes and comment that the letters were not included in Letters Home. Both letters retyped together on a single page.

did.unittitle: Typed copy of a letter from Alfred Young Fisher to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed copy of a letter to Sylvia Plath, congratulating her on her appointment to teach at Smith College. Copy presumably typed by Aurelia Plath, with her contextual notes and comment that the letters were not included in Letters Home. Both letters retyped together on a single page.

did.unittitle: Letter from Forecast to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Roger J. Coward, supplement editor, soliciting contributions of poetry or prose for a supplement to Forecast, the University of North Wales' newspaper, for its Arts Festival in March.

did.unittitle: Letter from Harper & Brothers to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Elizabeth Lawrence, expressing interest in any book she might submit to Harper & Brothers and complimenting her story "The Daughters of Blossom Street." She also says she will write again when she can "report more definitely on the reception of Lupercal."

did.unittitle: Letter from Harper & Row to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Elizabeth Lawrence, explaining why Harper & Row will not publish The Bell Jar and hoping to see other writing by her.

did.unittitle: Letter from Harper's Magazine to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from R.B. Silvers, editor, telling her that they will publish her poem, Mushrooms.

did.unittitle: Letter from Harper's Magazine to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from R.B. Silvers, editor, offering to buy her poems, Sleep in the Mojave Desert and You're.

did.unittitle: Letter from Dorothea (Doris) Krook to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph note (signed) to Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes, on postcard, Christmas and New Year's greetings from Doris.

did.unittitle: Letter from The London Magazine to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Charles Osborne (assistant editor of The London Magazine from 1958-1966. ) commenting on poems she has submitted for publication: "I thought the poems you sent most exciting, and just to bolster my editorial self-respect, I finally managed to find two or three to send back to you! The remainder we'll keep."

did.unittitle: Letter from The London Magazine to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Alan Ross, telling her they want to print her story, "The Fifty-Ninth Bear."

did.unittitle: Letter from The London Magazine to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Alan Ross, advising her that her poems "Stopped Dead" and "The Applicant" will be published in January, and offering to pay her for them now.

did.unittitle: Letter from James Michie to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, telling her that Alfred A. Knopf wants to publish The Colossus if she leaves out one poem "that they think is too Roethkesque." He suggests that she accept Knopf's terms.

did.unittitle: Letter from Marianne Moore to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed, with a holograph postscript) to Sylvia Plath, agreeing to provide a reference for the Saxton Fellowship and commenting on Plath's poetry: "… don't be quite so grisly."

did.unittitle: Letter from Susan Moore to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, asking when they can meet each other.

did.unittitle: Letter from My Weekly to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, from Helena F. Annan, declining to publish her stories "Shadow Girl" and "A Winter's Tale," and detailing the sort of story My Weekly publishes; she mentions that My Weekly did publish Plath's story "The Lucky Stone."

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Howard Moss, accepting "Mussel Hunter at Rock Harbor" and "Nocturne" for publication. Moss also mentions scheduling problems, suggests a title and punctuation changes, and asks her to clarify several points in "Mussel Hunter."

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from William Maxwell, rejecting her stories for The New Yorker, but inviting her to "come in, some day, and talk about stories."

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Robert Hemenway, accepting two of her poems, "On Deck" and "Two Campers in Cloud Country," if she will make certain changes in them.

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Howard Moss, explaining the features of a first-reading agreement with The New Yorker, which he hopes she will accept. With "first reading" agreement", signed by R. Hawley Truax, vice-president of The New Yorker Magazine, Inc.

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Howard Moss, returning some poems and commenting at length on "Elm" and why they are wary of publishing it in its present form.

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Howard Moss, telling her they will publish "Elm", but would like the title to be "The Elm Speaks" to avoid confusion about the speaker in the poem. Moss also returns other rejected poems: "… none of them seemed to us quite as splendid as 'Elm'."

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Howard Moss, rejecting ten of her poems, but keeping two for further consideration.

did.unittitle: Letter from The New Yorker to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath from Howard Moss, sending back rejected poems and offering to print the second section of "Amnesiac" by itself, if she wants to re-submit it that way.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ralph O'Reily to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, praising her poem "Mushrooms."

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Removed from Plath's Album of Clippings, page 75.

did.unittitle: Photocopy of letter from Ilo Phil to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, enclosing illustrations that Ilo has created for Sylvia's story "Den of Lions."

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Original in Writing, Artwork, and Memorabilia of Others.

did.unittitle: Letter from Aurelia Schober Plath to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (carbon) to Syliva Plath, responding to her letter of 11/11/54. Newsy letter about her new typewriter, her father's upcoming 74th birthday, people's favorable reactions to Sylvia's poems, and her reasons for wanting Sylvia not to fly in airplanes while at Smith.

did.unittitle: Telegram from Aurelia Schober Plath to Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Telegram to Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes, with two postcards of the S.S. United States.

did.unittitle: Letter from Aurelia Schober Plath to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, concerning domestic matters, books she has read, and family news.

did.unittitle: Letter from Aurelia Schober Plath to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, discussing her move to London, news of home, and her separation from Ted.

did.unittitle: Letter from Poetry to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, telling her she has won the Bess Hokin Prize of $100 for her poems published in Poetry that year, signed by Henry Rago, editor.

did.unittitle: Letter from Poetry to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from Henry Rago to Sylvia Plath, accepting her poems "Fever 103º," "Purdah," and "Eavesdropper" for publication, with printed "notice of acceptance."

did.unittitle: Letter from Olive Higgins Prouty to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter to Sylvia Plath, discussing domestic matters and Sylvia's poem "Candles."

did.unittitle: Letter from Olive Higgins Prouty to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, telling her what her lawyer said about alimony, joint property, etc., and urging her to put pressure on Ted to provide support for his children.

did.unittitle: Letter from Olive Higgins Prouty to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, enclosing a check and discussing her domestic situation, including Ted (Hughes') weekly visits to Frieda, his payments, etc., and admiring her courage.

did.unittitle: Letter from Punch to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, thanking her for her "schooldays piece" which they will publish, signed by Bernard Hollowood, editor.

did.unittitle: Letter from John Richardson to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, inviting her to a Spike Milligan evening on March 3rd.

did.unittitle: Letter from Stevie Smith to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, thanking her for her letter and hoping they meet after she moves to London.

did.unittitle: Postcard from Jack Sweeney to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph note (signed) to Sylvia Plath, on a picture postcard with a Klee painting, complimenting her on her poem, "Poem for Paul Klee's Perseus."

did.unittitle: Letter from The Times Literary Supplement to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) to Sylvia Plath, writing that they are "delighted to print… 'The Hermit at Outermost House' and 'Two Views of a Cadaver Room'" and hoping she will let them publish a collection of her poems "you may produce at any time." Signed by Alan Pryce-Jones, editor.

did.unittitle: Photocopy of letter from Assia Weevil to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopy of a typed letter (signed) to "Sylvia," 22 May [196-?] Concerns tapestry materials and instructions.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Original in British Library, London

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Eilat Negev and Yehuda Koren, 02/23/2001.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) from James Michie to Sylvia Plath, asking her to consider Heinemann as a potential English publisher for her first volume of poetry.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) from James Michie to Sylvia Plath, telling her that Heinemann would like to publish her poems.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from Elizabeth Anderson to Sylvia Plath, telling her that Alfred A. Knopf has decided not to publish The Bell Jar, but would be interested in her future writing; says she will offer The Bell Jar to another American publisher.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from Elizabeth Anderson to Sylvia Plath, saying she has sent a copy of The Bell Jar to Elizabeth Lawrence of Harper & Row.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from David Machin to Sylvia Plath, sending her an advance copy of The Bell Jar.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from David Machin to Sylvia Plath, congratulating her on her recent "excellent reviews" and asking her to call to arrange a time for them to meet.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from David Machin to Sylvia Plath, asking her about their missed lunch date the day before.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Heinemann, Ltd. to Ted Hughes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (signed) from David Machin to Ted Hughes, about the reprint of The Bell Jar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are photocopies of all correspondence, from Plath and to Plath.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically with undated correspondence at the end.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The originals are filed in Correspondence: From Plath (alphabetically by the recipient) and Correspondence: To Plath (alphabetically by the writer).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plath's personal papers include an address book, her 1963 engagement calendar, financial materials, memorabilia, notes, and a scrapbook (from which the clippings were removed).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Address book includes names and addresses of family, friends, other writers, publishers, and publications. Most entries are in Sylvia Plath's hand; some written by Ted Hughes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letts Royal Office Tablet Diary. Handwritten entries by Sylvia Plath for virtually every day, providing details of domestic life (baking, shopping lists, etc.) and professional appointments and deadlines for work (book reviews, etc.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small spiral notebook with lists of earnings (including prizes), expenses (books, shoes, room and board, etc.), and bank account totals in Plath's hand. "Dick Norton" is written on the front cover. Some pages are loose and two pages are written by Aurelia Plath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript accounting by Plath of deposits and balances in her savings account. 1961 August has a withdrawal of money marked "House deposit."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Checkbook stubs in an envelope from LLoyd's Bank. There is a list of poems in Plath's hand on the back, in two columns headed "Harper's" and "Observer".

did.unittitle: Financial materials: Receipt from The Kenyon Review

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Receipt for payment of $25.00 for "verse in The Kenyon Review, Autumn 1960." The poems "The Colossus" and "The Beekeeper's Daughter" appeared in this issue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed legal document (one page is a photostat) in which The New Yorker Magazine, Inc., transfers to Sylvia Plath the "right, title and interest" in the copyrights to four of her poems, which appeared in The New Yorker from August 1958 - May 1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten calculations in Plath's hand on the back of an envelope from LLoyd's Bank (postmarked 1961 June 14). According to Ted Hughes, calculations pertain to the purchase of Court Green, their home in Devon. The calculations show checkbook deposits and checks written (#794-816). "June 1" is written on the bottom of the right hand column. Ted Hughes has recorded two other expenses on the front of the envelope, dated 1961 Nov 4 and 1962 Mar 23.

did.physdesc: Printed card with pink trim and ribbon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Birth announcement for Sylvia Plath with "Sylvia Plath 8 3/4 lbs.," parents' names, and date written on the card, along with the message "Mother and baby are fine!"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcard from the Quiz Kids program thanking Sylvia Plath for the question she submitted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: List of book titles and call numbers of books by Frank R. Leavis, in Plath's hand. List is on the back of a library catalogue card.

did.unittitle: Memorabilia: Ceramic tile and pendant from Seventeen Magazine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ceramic tile and pendant in the form of the numeral '17'. Paper attached to the tile has the printed message, "Holiday Greetings from all of us at Seventeen."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten shopping list on the back of a Smith College Official Class card, 2nd semester 1957-58, for Emmy Thomas Pettway, for English 11.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Found in Plath's copy of T.S. Eliot, by Elizabeth Drew (Mortimer Rare Book Collection, 825 P696L Dr.).

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Found in Plath's copy of Cleanth Brooks' Understanding Poetry pages 554-55 (Mortimer Rare Book Collection, 825 P696L Br).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopies of covers of piano sheet music owned by Sylvia Plath. Four leaves have her signature; three have notes by Aurelia Plath.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Original sheet music in Newnham College, Cambridge Archives.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Sheet music was left by Plath in her rooms at Newnham College, circa 1956.

did.unittitle: Memorabilia: Maps of Paris, Nice, and France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Maps of Paris, Nice, and France with the name of a hotel and room number written by Plath inside the front cover. Also with handwritten note by Aurelia Plath.

did.unittitle: Memorabilia: Front cover of Audience: A Quarterly Review of Literature and the Arts
Memorabilia: Dust jacket to Light Blue Dark Blue: An Anthology of Oxford & Cambridge Writing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dust jacket only. The list of writers includes Ted Hughes. Ted Hughes' "Macaw and Little Miss" was published in the 1960 edition of Light Blue Dark Blue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript lists Sylvia Plath's birth date, degrees, awards, and jobs through 1959. "Palatino," possibly instructions to a printer, is written at the bottom.

did.unittitle: Memorabilia: Notes from Ted Hughes to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two handwritten notes from Ted to Sylvia and one riddle from Sylvia to Ted in an envelope with typing, "Handwritten verses from Ted to Sylvia that accompanied gifts and special occasions."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed bookmark inscribed, "Love - Sylvia & Ted." "Ted" is in Ted Hughes' hand.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Elinor Friedman Klein, Smith College class of 1956, 01/31/1999.

did.physdesc: Written on pink Smith College memorandum paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten lists of French/English vocabulary, and a short list of works by Jean-Paul Sartre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One page typed (carbon), in German, titled Zwolftausend, with handwritten signature and annotations in ink by Plath (in English and German). One page handwritten notes by Plath, in English, with German study schedule.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Found in Plath's copy of: Roseler, Robert Oswald. German in review. New York, 1953 (MRBC 825 P696L Ros).

did.physdesc: Written on pink Smith College memorandum paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes of German/English vocabulary and passages in German.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous list of titles and library call numbers of books by and about Ibsen.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Found (laid in front) in Plath's copy of : Sophocles. The Theban Plays [Harmondsworth, Middlesex, 1956] (MRBC 825 P296L Sot).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes, headed: JUNG. One-half page of translations from St. John Perse. Notes include items on the development of personality and on marriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes by Plath possibly from an interview (?) with Marvin Kane. Page headed: Marvin Kane 9 Holland Park London W. 11 Park 6928.

did.physdesc: On pink Smith College memorandum paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two handwritten quotations, with page references, from Melville's Moby Dick.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Found in Plath's copy of Melville's Moby Dick (MRBC 825 P696L Mel).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes outline of a book about "Nancy," poems and phrases, and a story titled "The thrilling journies of a penny." Written in memorandum notebook. "Sylvia Plath, 1944" written on cover. "O.E. Plath" embossed on cover. Handwritten note by Aurelia Plath: "(Jr. High School age) Plan for a book."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes by Plath possibly for a review of poems (?) by William Stafford. Written on an envelope (postmark: 1961 Mar 21).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stream-of-consciousness description: typescript and handwritten sentence, in quotations, about rain and fog.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook and photocopies of separated pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sylvia Plath created an album of clippings of three dozen of her poems, four articles, one letter, and one review of her poem "Spinster" in a commercial album. This box contains the original album with blank pages and photocopies of the separated materials. Photocopies note their original page number in the album. Some pages of the album have handwritten captions remaining.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: All of the original clippings were removed from the album.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Originals are filed in the poems, prose, reviews, and correspondence series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains papers written, and sometimes illustrated, by Plath in Junior and Senior High School, as well as items from Smith College and Cambridge University.

Crawford to Aurelia Plath, thanking her for sending her daughter's registration fee and placing Sylvia on the list of applicants for admission to college. With two typed pages headed "To Candidates for Admission in 1950." Handwritten annotations are by Aurelia Plath.

scopecontent.p: Autograph letter (signed) from Mary C. Ford to Aurelia Plath announcing $400 scholarship from Wellesley Smith Club for 1951-1952. Also included are envelope, and typed draft of Aurelia's response dated 1951 May 13 as well as a handwritten note by Aurelia about Sylvia Plath's scholarship grants.

did.unittitle: Smith College: Letter from K. Frances Scott to Sylvia Plath

did.unittitle: Smith College: Postcard from K. Frances Scott to Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.p: Typed postcard from K. Frances Scott to Sylvia Plath informing her that her name has been placed on the list to take the hygiene exemption examination, with annotation by Aurelia Plath indicating that Sylvia took the exam and was exempted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Who's Who in 1954, Smith College, fall 1950, with typed letter (signed) from Mary McBreen (Smith College class of 1952) asking for submissions for the "Who's Who…." Freshman class welcome booklet. The cover has the signature of Enid Lois Epstein and book is annotated by her. Entry, with photograph, of Plath on p. 36.

scopecontent.p: Holograph notes for Notes for English 211: 20th century, Miss Drew (Fall term of English 211: 19th century).

did.unittitle: Smith College: Letter from Benjamin F. Wright to Aurelia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter from Benjamin F. Wright, president of Smith College, to Aurelia Plath announcing a raise in tuition for 1951-1952 with envelope, postmarked 1951 May 7.

did.unittitle: Smith College: Borrower's cards Neilson Library books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Borrower's cards removed from Neilson Library books, with "S. Plath '54" written as one of many borrowers. Due dates May 19, 1951, April 2, 1953, and May 28, 1953. Cards for books by Elizabeth Bowen and by and about Edith Sitwell.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Removed from books in Neilson Library stacks.

did.unittitle: Smith College: The Smith College Associated News

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article from The Smith College Associated News about Plath as one of three candidates for Honor Board secretary, pages 3 and 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Smith Weekly Current volume 5, number 15, containing an article about Plath taking over as Honor Board Secretary, p. 5, and clipping of similar news from "Neighborhood News," in The Townsman (Wellesley, MA), 1952 May 1, page 20, stapled to page 5.

did.unittitle: Smith College: This is Smith College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is Smith College volume 4, number 1, article "Student self-government and responsible citizenship" by Enid Epstein, 54 (Smith College class of 1954). Article has handwritten annotations by Sylvia Plath and a photograph of her, as member of the Electoral Board, on page 2.

did.unittitle: Smith College: Notes for English 321b: American literature

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Holograph notes for Notes for English 321b: American literature, Mr. Arvin.

did.unittitle: Smith College: "A Check-list of the Published Writings of Gertrude Stein"

physdesc.extent: (8 pages and half sheet of errata)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "A Check-list of the Published Writings of Gertrude Stein" compiled by George James Firmage, Amherst: University of Massachusetts, 1954. "Sylvia Plath" is inscribed on front cover in her own hand. With half sheet of errata inserted.

did.unittitle: Smith College: Translation of Rainer Maria Rilke, "A Prophet."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript of Sylvia Plath's translation of Rainer Maria Rilke's "A Prophet" for German 12. One page is signed by Sylvia Plath with her handwritten changes. Includes a "literal" and "verse" translation. The second page is headed "Sylvia Plath German 12" and includes the completed translation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript of selected stanzas from poems by Sylvia Plath typed into two columns headed "Revisions" and "Alterations." One column is the original text, and the second is revision after comments by Alfred Young Fisher. Some underlining and a few comments (by Fisher) on "Revisions" page. May have been done for a Special Studies with Fisher.

did.unittitle: Smith College: Smith College commencement program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Commencement program with "Adlai Stevenson" (speaker) written by Aurelia Plath on the cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paintings, drawings, and collage made by Sylvia Plath. Plath often made drawings in her journals and her correspondence, as well as creating drawings and paintings, and both 'formal' and 'informal' creations are represented here. Originals of drawings and paintings are followed by photocopies of art that appears on items elsewhere in the collection. The location of the original is noted on the folder containing the photocopy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included here are photographs of Plath and family members. The list and descriptions here are taken from a photograph register originally created in 1998 (and updated in 2009 and 2013). Information sheets are included in the folder with each original photograph. Copyright holder contact information is in a folder at the back of Box 22.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These photographs are arranged in chronological order.

phystech.p: As a preservation measure, researchers must use digital copies of audiovisual materials in this collection. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request the creation of and access to digital copies.

did.unittitle: Poetry reading and comments by Sylvia Plath recorded live in Springfield, Massachusetts

container.altrender: Tall legal document box (15d x 12h x 5w)
container.label: Mixed Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audio recording of a reading by Sylvia Plath, poetry and comments, recorded live, Springfield, MA with an introduction by Lee Anderson, and a permission statement by Sylvia Plath at the end. Audio includes comments by Plath on the poems, her writing techniques, the incompatibility of teaching and writing, poets she reads, and on "what poetry should be," all in response to questions and comments (possibly by Anderson). Side 1: Black rook in rainy weather; The earthenware head; Departure of the ghost; The disquieting muses; Battle-scene from the comic operatic fantasy The seafarer; On the decline of oracles; Poem for Paul Klee's Perseus: the triumph of wit over suffering; On the difficulty of conjuring up a dryad; November graveyard; Sow; Spinster. Side 2: On the plethora of dryads; All the dead dears.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of George deF. Lord, English Department, Yale University, 01/06/1983.

did.unittitle: "Plath: Plath reads Plath. An interview: Sylvia Plath talks with Peter Orr of the British Council."

physdesc.extent: (1 audio cassette (46 minutes) + 1 sound disc (46 minutes) + mp3)

container.altrender: Tall legal document box (15d x 12h x 5w)
container.label: Mixed Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audio recording of "Plath: Plath reads Plath. An interview: Sylvia Plath talks with Peter Orr of the British Council." Recorded 1962 Oct 30 under the auspices of the British Council and the Woodberry Poetry Room, Harvard College Library (Cambridge, MA: Credo Records #3, 1975). Sound disc liner notes by Frances McCullough. Poems read: Amnesiac, The applicant, Ariel, A birthday present, Cut, Daddy, Fever 103º, Lady Lazarus, Medusa, Nick and the candlestick, Poppies in October, Purdah, Rabbit catcher, A secret, Stopped dead.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift (disc) of Joe Berk, record's producer, Sept 1975. With typed letter (1975 Sept 8) from Nancy Brownell, editor of the Smith Alumnae Quarterly, to Joe Berk, acknowledging his gift.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article by Corinne Robins in Mademoiselle pages 34-5. Article is about Sylvia Plath, Ted Hughes, Kathleen Fraser, and Howard Hart. Includes Sylvia Plath's poem "The Times are Tidy" and Ted Hughes' "Pennines in April," and a photograph of Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes by James Coyne. Annotations by Aurelia Plath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder includes articles, advertisements, and reviews concerning the use of Plath's writings in theatrical, dance, and musical productions. Works mentioned include: the Royal Shakespeare Company's productions of "Sylvia Plath," a dramatized setting of the poet's writing, including her only play "Three Women"; and, "Ariel" set to music.

did.unittitle: Photocopy typescript of "Ariel's Flight: the Death of Sylvia Plath"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopy typescript of "Ariel's Flight: the Death of Sylvia Plath" by Nancy J.C. Andreason M.D., Iowa City, IA: Department of Psychiatry, University of Iowa College of Medicine. Published in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Typescript has handwritten notes by Aurelia Plath throughout the articles and on T.L.s. Title page has the following handwritten not (not in Aurelia Plath's hand) "edical analysis of Sylvia Plath's illness, ascribing no responsibility to her medical treatment." Published in Saturday Evening Post 244 (March 1975) pages 58-59 and 78-80.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cambridge Review 90 with Durant's clipping slip. Contains "Early Poems by Sylvia Plath" ("Street Song," "Natural History," "Resolve," and "Aerialist") and six articles about Sylvia Plath (by A. Alvarez, George Steiner, David Holbrook, Eric Homberger, and M.W.C. [Wendy Campbell]). Each item is listed separately in this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence to and from Sylvia Plath's mother, Aurelia Schober Plath, as well as some personal papers, some writings by her, and some memorabilia relating to Sylvia Plath. There also is material concerning Letters Home, edited and with commentary by Aurelia Plath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters to and from Aurelia Plath. They include correspondence about Letters Home, a book containing many of Sylvia Plath's letters written to her mother. Aurelia Plath-Olwyn Hughes correspondence deals in large part with The Bell Jar.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged in alphabetical order by the name of Aurelia Plath's correspondent.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Unless noted otherwise, all Aurelia Plath correspondence is the Gift of Aurelia S. Plath, 12/03/1983.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Unless noted otherwise, all Aurelia Plath biographical materials are Gift of Aurelia S. Plath, 12/03/1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials concerning the life of Aurelia Plath. Early materials largely concern her education and later materials include a wedding invitation, an article about german cousins, a document concerning her career, and a photocopy of the typescript for "Aurelia Plath: a lasting commitment."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chronology, notes, and typescript of a talk concerning the life and works of Sylvia Plath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Memorabilia from Sylvia Plath's lifetime as well as two later items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents concerning Letters Home including typescripts, contracts, commentary, and reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents and objects (doctoral robes) belonging to Sylvia Plath's father, Otto Emil Plath. Documents include articles on Otto Plath's FBI files, an engraved portrait of Boston University president Daniel L. Marsh, and documents concerning Otto Plath's entry in Who's Who in American Education.

physdesc.extent: (8 boxes; 3 oversize folders; 1 folder in another series)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material written or edited by Ted Hughes, who was Sylvia Plath's husband, including correspondence, writings, documents concerning Syliva Plath's poems, and docoments concerning publications of Sylvia Plath's works after her death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters from Ted Hughes to various recipients and one letter from Olwyn Hughes to Ted Hughes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopy of holograph garden notes and a permit to reenter form from the United States Department of Justice Immigration and Naturalization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poems, plays, and reviews (drafts, typed copies, and printed copies) by Ted Hughes. The original copies of much of the material here are on the versos of Sylvia Platlh's writings. There also are some notations on Ted Hughes's writing identifying where the item was published. Some submission lists and lists of Ted Hughes's poetry earnings are included here (at the end of this subseries).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles about Ted Hughes and reviews of his work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ted Hughes' notes (some brief, some substantive) on Sylvia Plath's poems. These notes were likely Ted Hughes's method for organizing and labeling the poem drafts in preparation for their sale at auction.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Page proofs, for Faber and Faber 1967 edition. Written on half-title: "Mr. Hughes." Manuscript corrections by Ted Hughes.

did.unittitle: The Uncollected Poems by Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Galley proofs for the limited edition published in London by Turret Books, 1965. Some corrections in ink. Start of poem "Thalidomide," here titled "Half-moon," on last page, crossed out (not published in this volume). Note: Mortimer Rare Book Collection has printed book (825 P696un 1965).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed copies (not by Plath) of excerpts from some of her journals from 1957-1959, which were sealed from 1981 until 1998; also here are the two envelopes in which the sealed materials were delivered to Smith College with the rest of the Sylvia Plath Collection in 1981.

did.unittitle: The Collected Poems by Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are the working papers used to create The Collected Poems by Sylvia Plath (first U.S. edition: New York: Harper & Row, 1981). There are multiple copies of each poem, most of them photocopies of Plath's typed copies or of printed versions of the poems. There are some notes and dates added. The poem titles are not listed in this finding aid, but the 326 folders are arranged in four boxes alphabetically by the poem title, as published in The Collected Poems. The subseries does not contain original manuscripts, but is composed primarily of photocopies and typed copies of Sylvia Plath's poetry. The "M" on the top of some drafts may indicate the "master" copy that was used as the copy text for each poem published in The Collected Poems. Alphabetical lists of poems are also included and filed under "A" general, "B" general, etc.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the poem title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists primarily of reviews (newspapers and magazines, clippings, and photocopies) of Ted Hughes' Birthday Letters (a collection of his poems about Sylvia Plath, published in 1998). Also included are items relating to symposia about Birthday Letters, Ted Hughes, and Sylvia Plath, as well as a few video and audio tapes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These items are arranged alphabetically, primarily by the name of the publication in which they appear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, primarily between Olwyn Hughes (Ted Hughes' sister) and London publisher Peter Owen, concerning a proposed book of recollections of Sylvia Plath, to be edited by Lois Ames. Some of the correspondence also concerns changes in a book about Plath by Edward Butscher.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The correspondence is arranged in chronological order.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Clayton Fine Books (McConnell-Bohning Fund), 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Books from the library of Marcia Brown Stern including books by and about Sylvia Plath, some annotated and with mounted photographs by Marcia B. Stern.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Items in this series were donated 02/16/2012 by Marcia Brown Stern, Smith College class of 1954.

did.unittitle: Writings of others collected and edited by Sylvia Plath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains American Poetry Now (Critical Quarterly Poetry Supplement number 2), edited by Sylvia Plath (proofs and printed copies). It also has typescripts, clippings, and reprints of writing by others collected by Sylvia Plath. Some items have manuscript annotations by Plath. Details about the items are written on each folder. Some of these poems were included in American Poetry Now. There are also some notes by researchers relevant to this material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetical by author last name following copies and proofs of American Poetry Now.

did.unittitle: Writing, artwork, and memorabilia of others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains items relating to Sylvia Plath, created or collected by various people.
